p:
In order to become fusion-competent, SAR-CoVs S proteins must be cleaved by host proteases. In SARS-CoV-2, this process appears to be mediated primarily by TMPRSS2 in the plasma membrane.
65 TMPRSS2 (transmembrane protease, serine 2) is a transmembrane protein (predicted to have 492 aa) from the serine protease class (family: S1 clan: PA).
69
,
138 It is highly expressed in the epithelial cells of the prostate, and relatively less in lungs, colon, liver, kidney, and pancreas. Its physiological function is still unclear.
138 TMPRSS2 has a major role in SARS-CoV-2 cell entry and replication, and thus represents an interesting therapeutic target since its inhibitors could potentially block virus infection in its initial stages.
65
,
138 Potential TMPRSS2 blockers include some serine protease inhibitors [e.g., camostat mesylate (23)], commercially available compounds [e. g., ZINC64606047 (24), 3-[[5-(3-fluorophenyl)pyrimidin-2-yl]amino~(N)-(4-methyl phenyl)benzamide]] and natural products [e.g., withanone (25)].
65
